On 4/3/07, Bradley, Todd <todd.bradley@... > wrote:
>
> > What is the distinction between setup() and the constructor?
>
> I'm not sure if this is test runner specific behavior, but in my
> experience the constructors are all called at the same time, before any
> tests are run.  And then setUp() is run immediately before each test
> method is executed.  That's with JUnit 3.8.  I can't speak for version 4
> as we haven't switched yet.



For JUnit 3.8, that's correct.  Also, exceptions thrown from the constructor
will prevent the individual test method from being reported, while
exceptions thrown from setUp() are treated as test errors.

In JUnit 4, the differences are more subtle.  Test objects are constructed
right before execution, and exceptions thrown from constructors are handled
more gracefully, so you can choose based on style.  I usually put
initialization into field declarations or the constructor, unless I want to
show that a particular uninitialization sequence is paired with a particular
initialization sequence, in which case I'll use a paired @Before and @After
(the JUnit 4 version of setUp and tearDown).
